New Records: Shohei Ohtani became the first player in MLB history to reach 50 home runs and 50 stolen bases in the same season.
Ohtani is the first Japanese player to record a 50-homer season â€” and registered the 50th overall in MLB history.
Ohtani became the first Dodgers player to hit 50 home runs, breaking the previous franchise record of 49 set by Shawn Green in 2001.
Key Match Events: Ohtani hit three home runs and finished 6-for-6 with 10 RBIs, two doubles and a pair of stolen bases to power a 20-4 win over the Miami Marlins.
Ohtani homered and stole a base in the same game for the 13th time this season to equal the MLB mark set by Rickey Henderson in 1986.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers clinched a playoff berth with the victory, meaning Ohtani will compete in the MLB postseason for the first time in his career.
Post-Match Reflections: Ohtani said he was glad the team could make it to the playoffs and expressed his goal to perform well in the postseason.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Ohtani's big night came in the same stadium where he struck out his former Angels teammate Mike Trout to clinch the World Baseball Classic title for Japan in March 2023.
Ohtani's historic season has come during a whirlwind period for the superstar, including signing a 10-year, $700 million deal with the Dodgers and announcing his marriage in February.
Others: The Dodgers lead the San Diego Padres by four games in the race for the NL West division crown.
Ohtani leads the National League in home runs, RBIs (120) and on-base plus slugging percentage (1.005) and is fifth with a.294 batting average.
